Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Texas State University - San Marcos, STEM Rising Stars program, will be a four-year comprehensive effort designed to support college students pursuing science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) to feel confident and motivated about their future careers, to be academically successful, and to graduate on time. The project will increase understanding of successful ways to support and encourage female, Hispanic, and African American undergraduate students in STEM fields of study. Increasing STEM participation and graduation numbers for minority and female students will have a major impact on the production of a diverse and well-trained group of STEM graduates in Texas and potentially, at other large institutions across the country. This project will provide a model for how to recruit and retain student interest and participation in STEM education and will provide research insight as to how STEM instruction can be improved to be more effective.

Specific project goals at Texas State University over the next four years will be to: 1) increase the overall second-year STEM undergraduate student retention rate by 12% over four years to achieve a target of 62.5% retention; 2) increase the retention rate of Hispanic and African American STEM majors by 15% to achieve a target of 53% retention; 3) increase the overall representation of Hispanic and African American students (combined) in STEM majors by 20% over four years to achieve a target of 36% representation; and 4) increase the number of female students completing undergraduate STEM degrees by 25% over four years to achieve a target of 20% completion. These goals are guided by theoretical bases such as Tinto's academic and social integration model and Astin's involvement model, Tierney's model of persistence which suggests that institutions need to provide their students the cultural capital necessary to succeed in an educational system where barriers to persistence and integration exist for minority students, and the use of active learning methods. This project also considers contextual micro-level data that some theorists believe will help change agents understand what works and under what circumstances. Some of the contextual factors considered include: faculty and peer relationships, family and community support, and academic sense of self. By establishing communities of learners at both the student and faculty levels, Texas State STEM Rising Stars aims to make a significant and sustainable impact on the overall STEM learning culture at Texas State University. The project evaluation will involve a mixed-methods approach for formative and summative assessment. The formative assessment component will assess student participants' learning by measuring changes in their pre and post assessments, course grades, and the degree to which students report a continuing interest in STEM fields of study. The summative evaluation will monitor progress toward achieving project objectives and activities. In addition, the project will be conducting a persistence analysis, tracking student persistence and attrition among project participants. Texas State STEM Rising Stars is committed to producing significant improvements and has the faculty, partnerships, and infrastructure needed to assure success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM job growth will continue exceeding non-STEM job growth through 2024 and it would be remarkable that the emerging STEM workforce fits more closely the demography of the nation. In 2017, nearly 50% of the population were women and 26% were Hispanics and African Americans. However, the percentages of earned STEM degrees for these groups were much lower. By 2060, minorities will represent 56% of the population being crucial for universities to educate a more diverse STEM workforce to sustain economic growth, technological innovation and inter-group relations. Encouragingly, coordinated policy efforts are claiming to scale the adoption of evidence-based instructional practices and key strategies to support college students in their STEM courses and increase the number of degrees in STEM fields.

At Texas State University, a multidisciplinary team of faculty with research interests in engineering education, chemistry education, physics education, mathematics education, and computer science education implemented a collective impact research framework to identify relevant approaches to increase freshman and sophomore year STEM major retention and enrollment rates of females and under-represented minorities in chemistry, computer science, engineering, engineering technology, mathematics and physics.  With funding from the NSF IUSE program, the team developed the Texas State STEM Rising Stars, a collaborative learning and retention action research project to: (a) improve the campus sense of community for students, (b) establish innovative and robust STEM education research-based practices to support critical skill attainment for students and (c) support faculty understanding of the funds of knowledge of students. At that time, institutional data showed that STEM majors constituted about 7.7% of the overall undergraduate student population, about 32% of those STEM undergraduates were Hispanics and African Americans, 22.6% were women, and the 2nd-year retention rates for STEM students were 62.7%. The team adopted a common agenda with the objective of achieving 34% representation of Hispanic and African American students, 25% representation of female undergraduates and 67% retention rates for STEM undergraduates by 2018. In the past five years of this project, 4,750 undergraduate students have been impacted as direct participants and more than 1500 high school or community college students have participated in recruitment efforts. 

Intellectual Merit: The intervention ideas developed by the team include strategies to redesign courses; to provide mentoring and academic advising; to support supplemental instruction innovations; to establish learning communities; and to create academic and key skill development workshops critical for learners historically underrepresented in STEM and learners encountering new technologies. Towards the end of the project, objectives were met. STEM representation of Hispanic and African American students was about 46%, undergraduate female enrollment in STEM 25.2% and retention rates for STEM undergraduates 66.3%. Although there may be additional factors contributing to the achievement of the stated objectives, the analysis of student surveys, assessments and interview data show that the interventions provide effective support to the students involved at varying levels.  Notably, the expansion of Supplemental Instruction and Learning Assistant programs has had a major impact on the retention of students in chemistry, math, and science introductory courses. The redesign of an entry-level computer science course, the infusion of engineering design elements in a freshman-level university seminar course enhanced by the use of a maker space, the new students? orientations, and the creation of a special course to refine spatial visualization skills and create community among students have contributed to the increases in enrollment of female and underrepresented minorities.  The research generated by these interventions has contributed to the literature on how to create a learning community of faculty to positively impact student learning and attend to motivation and persistence of underrepresented students in STEM fields  and to engineering education topics such as, computer science education, first-year experience, spatial visualization skills and instructional innovation.

Broader Impacts: The positive student retention and success outcomes of this research project have contributed to improve the campus sense of community and the retention and representation rates of women, Hispanics, and African American STEM majors. Students impacted by the project are disseminating their positive experiences with STEM education to their co-workers and relatives contributing in a sustained way to narrow the gap in the representation of women, Hispanics and African Americans in the workforce. The project has provided insights into the effect of best practices to address the educational needs of a large public, Hispanic Serving Institution serving a diverse population of STEM students. It has served as a motivation to university administration and other faculty to support or scale those practices and to start similar interventions to fulfill other STEM gaps. The co-PI faculty have published 20 articles or conference presentations and are a part of national coordinated initiatives with similar goals. Another 300 faculty have participated in the STEM education community of practice. They received professional development and are ready to assist their students to improve in their STEM education pathways.
